text:
The **economy of Timor-Leste** is a lower-middle income economy as ranked by
the World Bank. It is placed 140th on the Human Development Index, indicating
a medium level of human development. 20% of the population is unemployed, and
52.9% live on less than $1.25 a day. About half of the population is
illiterate. At 27%, Timor-Leste's urbanisation rate is one of the lowest in
the world.

In 2007, a bad harvest caused a "major food crisis" in Timor-Leste. By
November, eleven sub-districts still needed food supplied by international
aid.

According to data gathered in the 2010 census, 87.7% of urban and 18.9% of
rural households have electricity, for an overall average of 36.7%.
openai_summarised_points: • The economy of Timor-Leste is classified as a lower-middle income economy according to the World Bank's ranking.
• Timor-Leste is ranked 140th on the Human Development Index, reflecting a medium level of human development within the country.
• The unemployment rate in Timor-Leste stands at 20%, indicating significant challenges in labor market absorption.
• A substantial portion of the population, specifically 52.9%, lives on less than $1.25 per day, highlighting widespread poverty.
• Approximately half of Timor-Leste’s population is illiterate, underscoring major educational deficits.
• The urbanisation rate in Timor-Leste is 27%, which is among the lowest urbanisation rates globally.
• In 2007, Timor-Leste experienced a major food crisis triggered by a poor harvest, severely impacting food security.
• By November 2007, eleven sub-districts in Timor-Leste still required food assistance supplied by international aid organizations.
• Data from the 2010 census reveals that 87.7% of urban households in Timor-Leste have access to electricity.
• In contrast, only 18.9% of rural households have electricity, resulting in an overall national average electricity access rate of 36.7%.

text:
Prior to and during colonisation, the island of Timor was best known for its
sandalwood. The Portuguese colonial administration also granted concessions to
Oceanic Exploration Corporation to develop oil and gas deposits. However, this
was curtailed by the Indonesian invasion in 1976.

Petrochemical resources were divided between Indonesia and Australia with the
Timor Gap Treaty in 1989. The treaty established guidelines for joint
exploitation of seabed resources in the area of the "gap" left by then-
Portuguese Timor in the maritime boundary agreed between the two countries in
1972. Revenues from the "joint" area were to be divided 50-50. Woodside
Petroleum and ConocoPhillips began development of some resources in the Timor
Gap on behalf of the two governments in 1992.

In late 1999, about 70% of the economic infrastructure of Timor-Leste was
destroyed by Indonesian troops and anti-independence militias, and 260,000
people fled westward. From 2002 to 2005, an international program led by the
United Nations, manned by civilian advisers, 5,000 peacekeepers (8,000 at
peak) and 1,300 police officers, substantially reconstructed the
infrastructure. By mid-2002, all but about 50,000 of the refugees had
returned.

The economy grew by about 10% in 2011 and at a similar rate in 2012.

While Timor-Leste gained revenue from offshore oil and gas reserves, little of
it has been spent on the development of villages, which still rely on
subsistence farming. As of 2012[update], nearly half the East Timorese
population was living in extreme poverty.
openai_summarised_points: • Prior to and during colonisation, the island of Timor was primarily known for its sandalwood, which was a significant natural resource during that period.
• The Portuguese colonial administration granted concessions to the Oceanic Exploration Corporation to develop oil and gas deposits in Timor, indicating early interest in petrochemical resources.
• The development of oil and gas deposits by Oceanic Exploration Corporation was curtailed following the Indonesian invasion of Timor in 1976.

• The Timor Gap Treaty, signed in 1989 between Indonesia and Australia, divided petrochemical resources in the Timor Gap area, which was a maritime boundary gap left by then-Portuguese Timor in the 1972 maritime boundary agreement.

• The Timor Gap Treaty established guidelines for joint exploitation of seabed resources in the Timor Gap, with revenues from the joint area to be divided equally, 50-50, between Indonesia and Australia.
• In 1992, Woodside Petroleum and ConocoPhillips began developing some oil and gas resources in the Timor Gap on behalf of the Indonesian and Australian governments under the terms of the treaty.

• In late 1999, approximately 70% of Timor-Leste’s economic infrastructure was destroyed by Indonesian troops and anti-independence militias, severely damaging the country’s economy and infrastructure.
• During the 1999 crisis, 260,000 people fled westward from Timor-Leste, creating a significant refugee situation.

• From 2002 to 2005, an international reconstruction program led by the United Nations, staffed by civilian advisers, 5,000 peacekeepers (peaking at 8,000), and 1,300 police officers, substantially rebuilt Timor-Leste’s destroyed infrastructure.
• By mid-2002, nearly all refugees had returned to Timor-Leste, with only about 50,000 remaining displaced.
• The economy of Timor-Leste experienced growth of approximately 10% in 2011 and maintained a similar growth rate in 2012, reflecting post-conflict economic recovery.

• Despite revenue generated from offshore oil and gas reserves, Timor-Leste has invested little of this income in the development of rural villages, where subsistence farming remains the primary livelihood.
• As of 2012, nearly half of the East Timorese population was living in extreme poverty, highlighting ongoing socio-economic challenges despite natural resource wealth.
• In 1993, Timor-Leste's nominal GDP was US$0.36 billion with a GDP per capita of US$480; no data available for GDP in PPP, growth rates, inflation, or government debt.
• In 1994, nominal GDP increased to US$0.43 billion and GDP per capita rose to US$561; other economic indicators remain unreported.
• By 1995, nominal GDP reached US$0.50 billion and GDP per capita was US$658; no additional economic data provided.
• In 1996, nominal GDP grew to US$0.61 billion with GDP per capita at US$801; no further economic statistics are available.
• The year 1997 saw nominal GDP at US$0.71 billion and GDP per capita at US$926; no data on PPP GDP, growth, inflation, or government debt.
• In 1998, nominal GDP sharply declined to US$0.25 billion and GDP per capita dropped to US$328; other economic metrics are not listed.
• The nominal GDP and GDP per capita remained stable in 1999 at US$0.25 billion and US$328 respectively, with no additional data.
• In 2000, GDP in PPP terms was recorded at US$1.1 billion, nominal GDP at US$0.37 billion, and GDP per capita at US$415; no data on growth, inflation, or debt.
• For 2001, GDP (PPP) increased to US$1.3 billion, nominal GDP to US$0.48 billion, and GDP per capita to US$530; other economic indicators are missing.
• In 2002, GDP (PPP) slightly decreased to US$1.2 billion, nominal GDP was US$0.47 billion, and GDP per capita was US$508; no further data provided.
• The year 2003 showed GDP (PPP) stable at US$1.2 billion, nominal GDP at US$0.49 billion, and GDP per capita at US$517; other figures are absent.
• In 2004, GDP (PPP) rose to US$1.3 billion, nominal GDP decreased to US$0.44 billion, and GDP per capita dropped to US$453; no additional data available.
• For 2005, GDP (PPP) was US$1.4 billion, nominal GDP US$0.46 billion, and GDP per capita US$464; other economic details are not reported.
• In 2006, GDP (PPP) decreased to US$1.3 billion, nominal GDP was US$0.45 billion, and GDP per capita was US$446; no further data provided.
• The year 2007 recorded GDP (PPP) at US$1.5 billion, nominal GDP at US$0.54 billion, and GDP per capita at US$523; no data on growth, inflation, or debt.
• In 2008, GDP (PPP) increased to US$1.7 billion, nominal GDP to US$0.65 billion, and GDP per capita to US$614; other economic indicators remain unreported.
• For 2009, GDP (PPP) was US$1.9 billion, nominal GDP US$0.73 billion, and GDP per capita US$676; no additional data available.
• In 2010, GDP (PPP) rose to US$2.1 billion, nominal GDP to US$0.88 billion, and GDP per capita to US$806; no further economic statistics are provided.
• The year 2011 saw GDP (PPP) at US$2.3 billion, nominal GDP at US$1.04 billion, and GDP per capita at US$936; other data points are missing.
• In 2012, GDP (PPP) increased to US$2.7 billion, nominal GDP to US$1.16 billion, and GDP per capita to US$1,024; no data on growth, inflation, or debt.
• For 2013, GDP (PPP) was US$2.9 billion, nominal GDP US$1.40 billion, and GDP per capita US$1,210; other economic indicators are not listed.
• In 2014, GDP (PPP) reached US$3.2 billion, nominal GDP was US$1.45 billion, and GDP per capita was US$1,232; no further data provided.
• The year 2015 recorded GDP (PPP) at US$3.5 billion, nominal GDP at US$1.59 billion, and GDP per capita at US$1,332; no additional economic data available.
• In 2016, GDP (PPP) rose to US$3.8 billion, nominal GDP to US$1.65 billion, and GDP per capita to US$1,353; other figures remain unreported.
• For 2017, GDP (PPP) slightly increased to US$3.9 billion, nominal GDP decreased to US$1.62 billion, and GDP per capita declined to US$1,299; no further data provided.
• In 2018, GDP (PPP) was US$4.0 billion, nominal GDP was US$1.58 billion, and GDP per capita was US$1,249; no additional economic statistics are available.
• The year 2019 showed a significant increase in GDP (PPP) to US$5.0 billion, nominal GDP rose to US$2.05 billion, and GDP per capita increased to US$1,583; other data points are missing.
• In 2020, GDP (PPP) surged to US$6.7 billion, nominal GDP decreased to US$1.90 billion, and GDP per capita declined to US$1,442; no data on growth, inflation, or government debt.
• For 2021, GDP (PPP) increased to US$7.3 billion, nominal GDP remained at US$1.90 billion, and GDP per capita stayed at US$1,442; other economic indicators are not reported.
• In 2022, GDP (PPP) rose substantially to US$9.4 billion, nominal GDP increased to US$2.45 billion, and GDP per capita grew to US$1,793; no further data provided.

• The year 2023 recorded a decrease in GDP (PPP) to US$5.1 billion, nominal GDP at US$1.99 billion, and GDP per capita at US$1,425; no data on real GDP growth, inflation, or government debt is available for this year.

text:
In the Doing Business 2013 report by the World Bank, Timor-Leste was ranked
169th overall and last in the East Asia and Pacific region. The country fared
particularly poorly in the "registering property", "enforcing contracts", and
"resolving insolvency" categories, ranking last worldwide in all three. In
2020 it ranked 181st. There are no patent laws in Timor-Leste.

Regarding telecommunications infrastructure, Timor-Leste is the second to last
ranked Asian country in the World Economic Forum's Network Readiness Index
(NRI), with only Myanmar falling behind it in Southeast Asia. In the 2014 NRI
ranking, Timor-Leste ranked number 141 overall, down from 134 in 2013.

Timor-Leste is part of the Timor Leste–Indonesia–Australia Growth Triangle
(TIA-GT).
openai_summarised_points: • In the World Bank's Doing Business 2013 report, Timor-Leste was ranked 169th overall globally and was the lowest-ranked country in the East Asia and Pacific region.
• Timor-Leste ranked last worldwide in the categories of "registering property," "enforcing contracts," and "resolving insolvency" according to the 2013 Doing Business report.
• By 2020, Timor-Leste's Doing Business ranking had declined further to 181st globally.
• Timor-Leste does not have any patent laws in place, indicating a lack of formal intellectual property protection.

• In terms of telecommunications infrastructure, Timor-Leste was the second lowest-ranked Asian country in the World Economic Forum's Network Readiness Index (NRI), with only Myanmar ranking lower in Southeast Asia.
• In the 2014 NRI, Timor-Leste was ranked 141st overall, which was a decline from its 2013 position of 134th.
• Timor-Leste is a member of the Timor Leste–Indonesia–Australia Growth Triangle (TIA-GT), a regional economic cooperation initiative involving these three countries.

text:
The agriculture sector employs 80% of Timor-Leste's active population. In
2009, about 67,000 households grew coffee in Timor-Leste, with a large
proportion of those households being poor. Currently, the gross margins are
about $120 per hectare, with returns per labour-day of about $3.70. There were
11,000 households growing mung beans as of 2009, most of them by subsistence
farming. 94% of domestic fish catch comes from the ocean, especially coastal
fisheries. 66% of families are in part supported by these subsistence
activities, however the country as a whole does not produce enough food to be
self-sustaining, and thus relies on imports. Coffee, rice, maize, coconuts,
cassava, soybeans, bananas, mango, and sweet potatoes are cultivated here.
With 5,014 Metric Tons in 2019, the country was ranked number 42 among other
countries in Avocados Production.

After petroleum, the second largest export is coffee, which generates about
$10 million a year. 9,000 tonnes of coffee, 108 tonnes of cinnamon, and 161
tonnes of cocoa were harvested in 2012 making the country the 40th ranked
producer of coffee, the 6th ranked producer of cinnamon and the 50th ranked
producer of cocoa worldwide. In 2019, 186 Metric Tons of cocoa beans were
produced and the country was number 48.
openai_summarised_points: • The agriculture sector in Timor-Leste employs 80% of the country's active population, highlighting its central role in the economy and livelihoods.
• In 2009, approximately 67,000 households in Timor-Leste were engaged in coffee cultivation, with a significant proportion of these households classified as poor.
• The gross margins for coffee production are currently about $120 per hectare, with labor returns estimated at approximately $3.70 per labor-day.
• As of 2009, there were 11,000 households growing mung beans, predominantly through subsistence farming methods.
• Domestic fish catch in Timor-Leste is predominantly ocean-based, with 94% of the catch coming from coastal fisheries.
• About 66% of families in Timor-Leste partially rely on subsistence activities such as fishing and small-scale agriculture for their support.
• Despite these subsistence activities, Timor-Leste does not produce sufficient food to be self-sustaining and depends on food imports to meet domestic demand.
• The primary crops cultivated in Timor-Leste include coffee, rice, maize, coconuts, cassava, soybeans, bananas, mangoes, and sweet potatoes.
• In 2019, Timor-Leste produced 5,014 metric tons of avocados, ranking it 42nd globally in avocado production.
• Coffee is the second largest export commodity after petroleum, generating approximately $10 million annually for Timor-Leste.
• In 2012, Timor-Leste harvested 9,000 tonnes of coffee, 108 tonnes of cinnamon, and 161 tonnes of cocoa.
• Based on 2012 production figures, Timor-Leste was ranked 40th worldwide in coffee production, 6th in cinnamon production, and 50th in cocoa production.
• In 2019, Timor-Leste produced 186 metric tons of cocoa beans, ranking 48th globally in cocoa production.

text:
The Portuguese colonial administration granted concessions to the Australia-
bound Oceanic Exploration Corporation to develop petroleum and natural gas
deposits in the waters southeast of Timor. However, this was curtailed by the
Indonesian invasion in 1976.[_citation needed_] The resources were divided
between Indonesia and Australia with the Timor Gap Treaty in 1989. Timor-Leste
inherited no permanent maritime boundaries when it attained
independence.[_citation needed_] A provisional agreement (the Timor Sea
Treaty, signed when Timor-Leste became independent on 20 May 2002) defined a
Joint Petroleum Development Area (JPDA) and awarded 90% of revenues from
existing projects in that area to Timor-Leste and 10% to Australia. An
agreement in 2005 between the governments of Timor-Leste and Australia
mandated that both countries put aside their dispute over maritime boundaries
and that Timor-Leste would receive 50% of the revenues from the resource
exploitation in the area (estimated at A$26 billion, or about US$20 billion
over the lifetime of the project) from the Greater Sunrise development. In
2013, Timor-Leste launched a case at the Permanent Court of Arbitration in The
Hague to pull out of a gas treaty that it had signed with Australia, accusing
the Australian Secret Intelligence Service (ASIS) of bugging the East Timorese
cabinet room in Dili in 2004.

At the time of independence Timor-Leste had per capita natural wealth
equivalent to the wealth of an upper-middle income country. Over half of this
was in oil, and over a quarter natural gas. The Timor-Leste Petroleum Fund was
established in 2005 to turn these non-renewable resources into a more
sustainable form of wealth. By 2009 it had a value of US$4.8 billion, and by
2011 it had reached a worth of US$8.7 billion. Timor-Leste is labelled by the
International Monetary Fund as the "most oil-dependent economy in the world".
The Petroleum Fund pays for nearly all of the government's annual budget,
which increased from $70 million in 2004 to $1.3 billion in 2011, with a $1.8
billion proposal for 2012. East-Timor's income from oil and gas stands to
increase significantly after its cancellation of a controversial agreement
with Australia, which gave Australia half of the income from oil and gas from
2006. From 2005 to 2021, $23 billion earned from oil sales has entered the
fund. $8 billion has been generated from investments, while $12 billion has
been spent. A decrease in oil and gas reserves led to decreasing HDI beginning
in 2010. 80% of government spending comes from this fund, which as of 2021 had
$19 billion, 10 times greater than the size of the national budget. As oil
income has decreased, the fund is at risk of being exhausted. Withdrawals have
exceeded sustainable levels almost every year since 2009.
openai_summarised_points: • The Portuguese colonial administration granted concessions to the Australia-bound Oceanic Exploration Corporation to develop petroleum and natural gas deposits in the waters southeast of Timor, but this development was curtailed by the Indonesian invasion in 1976.
• The Timor Gap Treaty of 1989 divided the petroleum and natural gas resources between Indonesia and Australia, leaving Timor-Leste with no permanent maritime boundaries upon its independence.

• Upon independence on 20 May 2002, Timor-Leste and Australia signed the Timor Sea Treaty, establishing a Joint Petroleum Development Area (JPDA) where Timor-Leste received 90% of revenues from existing projects, and Australia received 10%.

• A 2005 agreement between Timor-Leste and Australia mandated that both countries set aside their maritime boundary dispute, granting Timor-Leste 50% of revenues from resource exploitation in the Greater Sunrise development, estimated at A$26 billion (approximately US$20 billion) over the project’s lifetime.

• In 2013, Timor-Leste initiated a case at the Permanent Court of Arbitration in The Hague to withdraw from a gas treaty with Australia, accusing the Australian Secret Intelligence Service (ASIS) of bugging the East Timorese cabinet room in Dili in 2004.
• At independence, Timor-Leste’s per capita natural wealth was equivalent to that of an upper-middle income country, with over half of this wealth in oil and over a quarter in natural gas.

• The Timor-Leste Petroleum Fund was established in 2005 to convert non-renewable resource wealth into sustainable financial assets; by 2009, the fund was valued at US$4.8 billion and grew to US$8.7 billion by 2011.
• The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has labeled Timor-Leste as the "most oil-dependent economy in the world."
• The Petroleum Fund finances nearly all of the government’s annual budget, which increased from $70 million in 2004 to $1.3 billion in 2011, with a proposed budget of $1.8 billion for 2012.

• East Timor’s income from oil and gas was expected to increase significantly after canceling a controversial agreement with Australia that had given Australia half of the oil and gas income since 2006.
• From 2005 to 2021, $23 billion earned from oil sales was deposited into the Petroleum Fund; $8 billion was generated from investments, while $12 billion was withdrawn and spent.
• A decline in oil and gas reserves contributed to a decreasing Human Development Index (HDI) beginning in 2010.
• As of 2021, 80% of government spending was financed by the Petroleum Fund, which held $19 billion—approximately ten times the size of the national budget.
• Due to decreasing oil income, the Petroleum Fund is at risk of depletion, with withdrawals exceeding sustainable levels almost every year since 2009.

text:
Electricidade De Timor-Leste (EDTL) is the vertically integrated monopoly
generator and distributor of electric power within the on-grid areas.
openai_summarised_points: • Electricidade De Timor-Leste (EDTL) operates as the vertically integrated monopoly responsible for both the generation and distribution of electric power within the on-grid areas of Timor-Leste.

text:
In 2017, the country was visited by 75,000 tourists. Since the later 2010s,
tourism has been increasing and the number of hotels and resorts has
increased. The government decided to invest in the expansion of the
international airport in Dili.
openai_summarised_points: • In 2017, Timor-Leste received a total of 75,000 tourists visiting the country.
• Since the late 2010s, there has been a noticeable increase in tourism within Timor-Leste.
• Corresponding to the growth in tourism, the number of hotels and resorts in Timor-Leste has also increased.
• The government of Timor-Leste made a strategic decision to invest in the expansion of the international airport located in Dili to support and facilitate the growing tourism sector.

text:
* Betano Power Station
* Hera Diesel Power Plant

Protesters in Brisbane protesting Australia's claim on East Timorese oil, May
2017

One promising long-term project is the joint development with Australia of
petroleum and natural gas resources in the waters southeast of Timor-Leste.

Timor-Leste inherited no permanent maritime boundaries when it gained
independence, repudiating the Timor Gap Treaty as illegal. A provisional
agreement (the Timor Sea Treaty, signed when Timor-Leste became independent in
2002) defined a Joint Petroleum Development Area (JPDA), and awarded 90% of
revenues from existing projects in that area to Timor-Leste and 10% to
Australia. The first significant new development in the JPDA since East
Timorese independence is the largest petroleum resource in the Timor Sea, the
Greater Sunrise gas field. Its exploitation was the subject of separate
agreements in 2003 and 2005. Only 20% of the field lies within the JPDA and
the rest in waters not subject to the treaty (though claimed by both
countries). The initial, temporary agreement gave 82% of revenues to Australia
and only 18% to Timor-Leste.

The government of Timor-Leste has sought to negotiate a definite boundary with
Australia at the halfway line between the countries, in accordance with the
United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea. The government of Australia
preferred to establish the boundary at the end of the wide Australian
continental shelf, as agreed with Indonesia in 1972 and 1991. Normally a
dispute such as this would be referred to the International Court of Justice
or the International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea for an impartial
decision, but the Australian government had withdrawn from these international
jurisdictions (solely on matters relating to maritime boundaries) shortly
before East Timorese independence.

Nevertheless, under public and diplomatic pressure, the Australian government
offered instead a last-minute concession solely on royalties from the Greater
Sunrise gas field. An agreement was signed in 2005 under which both countries
would set aside the dispute over the maritime boundary, and Timor-Leste would
receive 50% of the revenues (estimated at A$26 billion or about US$20 billion
over the lifetime of the project) from the Greater Sunrise development. Other
developments within waters claimed by Timor-Leste but outside the JPDA
(Laminaria-Corallina and Buffalo) continue to be exploited unilaterally by
Australia, however.

Some proceeds from Timor-Leste's petroleum royalties are directed to the
country's sovereign wealth fund, the Timor-Leste Petroleum Fund.
openai_summarised_points: • In May 2017, protesters in Brisbane demonstrated against Australia’s claim on East Timorese oil, highlighting ongoing tensions over maritime resource rights between the two countries.
• A significant long-term economic project for Timor-Leste involves the joint development of petroleum and natural gas resources in the waters southeast of the country, in cooperation with Australia.
• Upon gaining independence, Timor-Leste inherited no permanent maritime boundaries and repudiated the Timor Gap Treaty as illegal, necessitating new agreements to manage resource exploitation.

• The Timor Sea Treaty, signed in 2002 when Timor-Leste became independent, established a provisional Joint Petroleum Development Area (JPDA) and allocated 90% of revenues from existing projects within the JPDA to Timor-Leste and 10% to Australia.

• The Greater Sunrise gas field, the largest petroleum resource in the Timor Sea, represents the first major new development in the JPDA since independence; it was subject to separate agreements in 2003 and 2005.

• Only 20% of the Greater Sunrise gas field lies within the JPDA, with the remaining 80% located in waters outside the treaty area but claimed by both Timor-Leste and Australia, complicating revenue sharing.
• An initial temporary agreement allocated 82% of Greater Sunrise revenues to Australia and only 18% to Timor-Leste, reflecting the contested nature of the field’s maritime boundaries.

• Timor-Leste’s government has pursued negotiation of a permanent maritime boundary with Australia based on the equidistant or halfway line principle, consistent with the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS).

• Australia preferred to establish the maritime boundary at the edge of its extensive continental shelf, as previously agreed with Indonesia in 1972 and 1991, creating a conflicting claim with Timor-Leste’s position.

• Typically, maritime boundary disputes would be resolved by the International Court of Justice or the International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea; however, Australia withdrew from these jurisdictions specifically regarding maritime boundary matters shortly before Timor-Leste’s independence.

• Under increasing public and diplomatic pressure, Australia made a last-minute concession in 2005, agreeing to share royalties from the Greater Sunrise gas field equally with Timor-Leste, setting aside the broader boundary dispute temporarily.

• The 2005 agreement granted Timor-Leste 50% of the revenues from the Greater Sunrise development, with estimated total revenues of approximately A$26 billion (about US$20 billion) over the project’s lifetime.

• Despite the 2005 agreement, Australia continues to unilaterally exploit other petroleum developments located in waters claimed by Timor-Leste but outside the JPDA, specifically the Laminaria-Corallina and Buffalo fields.

• Timor-Leste allocates a portion of its petroleum royalty proceeds to its sovereign wealth fund, known as the Timor-Leste Petroleum Fund, to manage and preserve resource revenues for future generations.
